senses.definition: material made by weaving wool, cotton, silk, etc., used for making clothes, curtains, etc. and for covering furniture

examples.en: They sell a wide variety of printed cotton fabric.
furnishing fabrics

senses.definition: the basic structure of a society, an organization, etc. that enables it to function successfully

examples.en: a trend which threatens the very fabric of society

senses.definition: the basic structure of a building, such as the walls, floor and roof

examples.en: The city retains much of its historic fabric.

senses.definition: extremely good

examples.en: They put on a fabulous performance.
Jana is a fabulous cook.
The food looks fabulous.
I want an outfit that'll make me look fabulous.

senses.definition: very great

examples.en: fabulous wealth/riches/beauty

senses.definition: appearing in fables

examples.en: fabulous beasts

senses.definition: the front part of the head, where the eyes, nose and mouth are

examples.en: a pretty/pale/round face
He buried his face in his hands.
to hide/cover your face
You should have seen the look on her face when I told her!
The expression on his face never changed.
She was red in the face with embarrassment.
At that time, her face was on the covers of all the magazines.

senses.definition: an expression that is shown on somebody’s face

examples.en: a smiling/happy/sad face
Her face lit up (= showed happiness) when she spoke of the past.
His face fell (= showed disappointment, sadness, etc.) when he read the headlines.
I could tell by his face it hadn't gone well.
Sue's face was a picture (= she looked very surprised, angry, etc.) as she listened to her husband's speech.

senses.definition: used to refer to a person of the type mentioned

examples.en: She looked around for a familiar face.
He's a fresh face (= somebody new) at the company.
It's nice to see some new faces here this evening.
The movie is full of famous faces.
a well-known face on our television screens
I'm tired of seeing the same old faces every time we go out!

senses.definition: having the type of face or expression mentioned

examples.en: pale-faced
a freckle-faced boy
grim-faced
a sad-faced woman

senses.definition: a side or surface of something

examples.en: the north face of the mountain
the dark face of the moon
A steep path zigzags down the cliff face.
We could see tiny figures climbing the rock face.
Ivy covered the front face of the house.
A banner hung across the face of the building.
How many faces does a cube have?

senses.definition: the front part of a clock or watch

examples.en: a dial like the face of a clock

senses.definition: the particular character of something

examples.en: the changing face of Britain
This discovery changed the whole face of science.
bureaucracy with a human face

senses.definition: a particular aspect of something

examples.en: Social deprivation is the unacceptable face of capitalism.
He has become the public face of the company.

idioms.word: be staring somebody in the face

senses.definition: used to describe something that you have failed to see, even though it was obvious and should have been easy to see

examples.en: The answer was staring us in the face but we never saw it until it was too late.

senses.definition: to be certain to happen

examples.en: Defeat was staring them in the face.

idioms.word: be staring something in the face

senses.definition: to be unable to avoid something

examples.en: They were staring defeat in the face.

idioms.word: be written all over somebody’s face

senses.definition: to be very obvious to other people from the expression on somebody’s face

examples.en: Guilt was written all over his face.

senses.definition: if a plan, etc. blows up in your face, it goes badly wrong in a way that causes you damage or makes you feel embarrassed

idioms.word: cut off your nose to spite your face

senses.definition: to do something when you are angry that is meant to harm somebody else but that also harms you

idioms.word: disappear/vanish off the face of the earth

senses.definition: to disappear completely

examples.en: Keep looking—they can't just have vanished off the face of the earth.

idioms.word: do something till you are blue in the face

senses.definition: to try to do something as hard and as long as you possibly can but without success

examples.en: You can argue till you're blue in the face, but you won't change my mind.

senses.definition: used to say that somebody will/will not get a particular job or position because they have/do not have the appearance, personality, etc. that the employer wants, even when this should not be important

examples.en: If your face fits, you'll get the job.
It doesn't matter how well qualified you are; if your face doesn't fit, you don't stand a chance.

idioms.word: somebody’s face is like thunder | somebody has a face like thunder

senses.definition: somebody looks very angry

examples.en: Mr Hibbs came in with a face like thunder.

senses.definition: close to and looking at somebody

examples.en: The two have never met face to face before.
The room fell silent as she came face to face with the man who had tried to kill her.

senses.definition: in a situation where you have to accept that something is true and deal with it

examples.en: She was at an early age brought face to face with the horrors of war.

senses.definition: with your face and stomach facing upwards/downwards

examples.en: She lay face down on the bed.

senses.definition: with the front part or surface facing upwards/downwards

examples.en: Place the card face up on the pile.
She placed the cards face down on the table.

senses.definition: to fall so that you are lying on your front
to fail completely, usually in an embarrassing way

examples.en: His next television venture fell flat on its face.

senses.definition: to eat a lot of food or too much food

idioms.word: fly in the face of something

senses.definition: to oppose or be the opposite of something that is usual or expected

examples.en: Such a proposal is flying in the face of common sense.

idioms.word: have the face to do something

senses.definition: to do something that other people think is rude or shows a lack of respect, without feeling embarrassed or ashamed

examples.en: I don't know how you have the face to complain after everything they've done for you!

idioms.word: have/be left with egg on/all over your face

senses.definition: to be made to look stupid

examples.en: They were left with egg on their faces when only ten people showed up.

senses.definition: annoying somebody by criticizing them or telling them what to do all the time

examples.en: Why are you always in my face?

senses.definition: despite problems, difficulties, etc.

examples.en: She showed great courage in the face of danger.
The campaign continued in the face of great opposition.

senses.definition: as a result of something

examples.en: He was unable to deny the charges in the face of new evidence.

senses.definition: to show in a very obvious way that you have no respect for somebody

idioms.word: laugh on the other side of your face

senses.definition: to be forced to change from feeling pleased or satisfied to feeling disappointed or annoyed

examples.en: He’ll be laughing on the other side of his face when he reads my letter.

senses.definition: (to have) an unhappy or disappointed expression

examples.en: He took one look at her long face and said ‘What’s wrong?’
The news for the company isn't good, to judge from the long faces in the boardroom.

senses.definition: to look straight at somebody without feeling embarrassed or ashamed

examples.en: Can you look me in the eye and tell me you're not lying?
She looked her father straight in the eye and answered his question truthfully.
I'll never be able to look her in the face again!

senses.definition: to be less respected or look stupid because of something you have done

examples.en: Many leaders don't want to lose face by admitting failures.

senses.definition: the state of being less respected by other people or looking stupid because of something you have done

examples.en: Failure to pass the exams means a massive loss of face for the students and their parents.

senses.definition: used to emphasize that you have particular skills or qualities

examples.en: ‘I didn't know you could play the piano.’ ‘I'm not just a pretty face, you know!’

senses.definition: used to say that something seems to be good, true, etc. but that this opinion may need to be changed when you know more about it

examples.en: On the face of it, it seems like a great deal.
What may, on the face of it, seem obvious often turns out to be far more complicated.

idioms.word: (as) plain as a pikestaff | (as) plain as day | (as) plain as the nose on your face

senses.definition: very obvious
to produce an expression on your face to show that you do not like somebody/something or in order to make somebody laugh

examples.en: What are you pulling a face at now?
Do you think it’s funny to make faces behind my back?

senses.definition: to put on make-up

idioms.word: put on a brave face | put a brave face on something

senses.definition: to pretend that you feel confident and happy when you do not

examples.en: I had to put on a brave face and try to show him that I wasn’t worried.
He put a brave face on his illness.

senses.definition: to avoid or help somebody avoid being embarrassed

examples.en: She was fired, but she saved face by telling everyone she'd resigned.

senses.definition: to be determined to oppose somebody/something

examples.en: It is a shame that the council has set its face against the scheme.

senses.definition: to appear among your friends or in public

examples.en: She stayed at home, afraid to show her face.

idioms.word: shut/slam the door in somebody’s face

senses.definition: to shut a door hard when somebody is trying to come in
to refuse to talk to somebody or meet them, in a rude way
a rude way of telling somebody to be quiet or stop talking
an action that seems to be intended as a deliberate way of offending and showing lack of respect for somebody

examples.en: The closure of the school is a slap in the face to the local community.

senses.definition: if you keep a straight face, you do not laugh or smile, although you find something funny
if you say something to somebody’s face, you say it to them directly rather than to other people

examples.en: He’s a liar, and I’ve told him so to his face many times.

senses.definition: used to refer to a person whose name you cannot remember

examples.en: Are you still working for what's her face?

idioms.word: wipe somebody/something off the face of the earth | wipe something off the map

senses.definition: to destroy or remove somebody/something completely
to be opposite somebody/something; to have your face or front pointing towards somebody/something or in a particular direction

examples.en: She turned and faced him.
Most of the rooms face the sea.
They face each other across the aisle.
The terrace faces south.
a north-facing wall
a south-east-facing garden
to face outwards/inwards/upwards/downwards
Lie with your palms facing upwards.
Which direction are you facing?

senses.definition: if you face a particular situation, or it faces you, you have to deal with it

examples.en: Farmers face serious challenges in these conditions.
We are facing a financial crisis.
to face charges/trial
the problems faced by homeless people
The project faces numerous difficulties.
They face competition from foreign imports.
She has faced criticism from some within her party.
We look at the issues facing schools today.
the challenges/problems that face the country
We are faced with the prospect of defeat.

senses.definition: to accept that a difficult situation exists, although you would prefer not to

examples.en: It's time to face reality—we failed.
It's not always easy to face the truth.
I did something wrong and I will face the consequences.
She had to face the fact that her life had changed forever.
Face facts—she isn't coming back.
Let's face it, we're not going to win.

senses.definition: if you can’t face something unpleasant, you feel unable or unwilling to deal with it

examples.en: I just can't face work today.
He wasn't able to face the washing up.
I can't face seeing them.
She could never face arguing with him.

senses.definition: to talk to or deal with somebody, even though this is difficult or unpleasant

examples.en: How can I face Tom? He'll be so disappointed.

senses.definition: to cover a surface with another material

examples.en: a brick building faced with stone

senses.definition: to accept and deal with criticism or punishment for something you have done

examples.en: The others all ran off, leaving me to face the music.

senses.definition: to make an action or a process possible or easier

examples.en: The new trade agreement should facilitate more rapid economic growth.
Structured teaching facilitates learning.

senses.definition: buildings, services, equipment, etc. that are provided for a particular purpose

examples.en: leisure/sports facilities
medical/recreational/educational facilities
shopping/banking/cooking facilities
Recycling facilities are provided.
The school is upgrading its outdoor play facilities.
They provide facilities management services to corporations, hospitals and universities.
There are not enough facilities for families with young children.
All rooms have private facilities (= a private bathroom).

senses.definition: a place, usually including buildings, used for a particular purpose or activity

examples.en: the world’s largest nuclear waste facility
a new healthcare facility
a production/manufacturing/research/storage facility
a detention/correctional facility (= a prison)

senses.definition: a special feature of a machine, service, etc. that makes it possible to do something extra

examples.en: a bank account with an overdraft facility
This facility allows the user to input text in various forms onto the screen and thus create a true newspaper page.
a facility for checking spelling

senses.definition: a natural ability to learn or do something easily

examples.en: She has a facility for languages.
He plays the piano with surprising facility.

senses.definition: a thing that is known to be true, especially when it can be proved

examples.en: First, some basic facts about healthy eating.
Isn't it a fact that the firm is losing money?
It's a well-known fact that dogs have an acute sense of smell.
I know for a fact (= I am certain) that she's involved in something illegal.
The report is based on hard facts (= information that can be proved to be true).
Get your facts right (= make sure your information is correct) before you start making accusations.
It's about time you learnt to face (the) facts (= accepted the truth about the situation).
We didn't get on well, and that's a fact.
The judge instructed both lawyers to stick to the facts of the case.

senses.definition: things that are true rather than things that have been invented

examples.en: The story is based on fact.
Is the account fact or fiction?
This is simply historical fact.
It's important to distinguish between fact and opinion.

senses.definition: used to refer to a particular situation that exists

examples.en: I could no longer ignore the fact that he was unhappy.
We don't hide the fact that we've made mistakes.
I did everything I could, and she acknowledged the fact.
Students are already highly media-literate and the curriculum needs to reflect this fact.
The very fact that this happened more than once shows there is a problem.
Despite the fact that she was wearing a seat belt, she was thrown sharply forward.
Due to the fact that they did not read English, the prisoners were unaware of what they were signing.
She was happy apart from the fact that she could not return home.

examples.cf: in view of the fact that…
examples.en: Voluntary work was particularly important in view of the fact that women were often forced to give up paid work on marriage.
We want to celebrate the simple fact of their being here.
The mere fact of being poor can put children at an educational disadvantage.
The fact remains that we are still two teachers short.

senses.definition: after something has happened or been done, when it is too late to prevent it or change it

examples.en: On some vital decisions employees were only informed after the fact.

senses.definition: used to add a comment on something that you have just said, usually adding something that you think the other person will be interested in

examples.en: It's a nice place. We've stayed there ourselves, as a matter of fact.

senses.definition: used to disagree with something that somebody has just said

examples.en: ‘I suppose you'll be leaving soon, then?’ ‘No, as a matter of fact I'll be staying for another two years.’

senses.definition: used to emphasize a statement, especially one that is the opposite of what has just been mentioned

examples.en: A new car would be wonderful but the fact of the matter is that we can't afford one.

senses.definition: a situation that cannot be changed, especially one that is unpleasant

examples.en: Illness is just a fact of life.
It’s a fact of life that some people will always be racist.

senses.definition: accurate and detailed information

examples.en: I've asked to see all the facts and figures before I make a decision.
All the facts and figures were presented at the meeting.

senses.definition: the details about sex and about how babies are born, especially as told to children
it is not necessary to give any further explanation about something because the information that is available already proves that it is true
used to give extra details about something that has just been mentioned

examples.en: I used to live in France; in fact, not far from where you're going.

senses.definition: used to emphasize a statement, especially one that is the opposite of what has just been mentioned

examples.en: I thought the work would be difficult. In actual fact, it's very easy.

senses.definition: used to say what is true in a situation

examples.en: In point of fact, she is their adopted daughter.

senses.definition: used to reply to a statement that you find interesting or surprising, or that you do not believe

examples.en: ‘She says I'm one of the best students she's ever taught.’ ‘Is that a fact?’

senses.definition: a small group of people within a larger one, whose members have some different aims and beliefs to those of the larger group

examples.en: There are rival factions within the administration.

senses.definition: opposition, disagreement, etc. that exists between small groups of people within an organization or political party

examples.en: a party divided by faction and intrigue

senses.definition: films, books, etc. that combine fact with fiction (= imaginary events)
one of several things that cause or influence something

examples.en: Obesity is a major risk factor for heart disease.
the key/crucial/deciding factor
Criminality is associated with a range of individual, family and environmental factors.
The result will depend on a number of different factors.
The closure of the mine was the single most important factor in the town's decline.
We have identified a few key factors in the project's success.

senses.definition: a number that divides into another number exactly

examples.en: 1, 2, 3, 4, 6 and 12 are the factors of 12.

senses.definition: the amount by which something increases or decreases

examples.en: The real wage of the average worker has increased by a factor of over ten in the last 70 years.

senses.definition: a particular level on a scale of measurement

examples.en: a suntan lotion with a protection factor of 10
The wind-chill factor will make it seem colder.

senses.definition: a substance in the blood that helps the clotting process. There are several types of this substance.

examples.en: Haemophiliacs have no factor 8 in their blood.

senses.definition: the feeling of confidence in the future that is shared by many people

examples.en: After the recession, people were waiting for the return of the feel-good factor before starting to spend money again.

senses.definition: a building or group of buildings where goods are made, mainly by machine

examples.en: a car factory
The factory closed down ten years ago.
She works in the local textile factory.
factory workers

senses.definition: a person or organization that continuously produces a large quantity of a particular thing

examples.en: This record label has become a real hit factory (= one that produces a lot of successful songs).
These universities are becoming colourless degree factories, with no sense of what higher learning is really about.

senses.definition: a department or group of related departments in a college or university

examples.en: the Faculty of Law
students who are doing degrees in the Arts Faculty
the Faculty of Arts

senses.definition: all the teachers in a faculty of a college or university

examples.en: the Law School faculty
a faculty meeting
faculty members
The faculty is/are meeting to discuss the issue.

senses.definition: all the teachers of a particular university or college

examples.en: faculty members
She joined the faculty of the University of Maryland.

senses.definition: any of the physical or mental abilities that a person is born with

examples.en: the faculty of sight
She retained her mental faculties (= the ability to think and understand) until the day she died.
to be in full possession of your faculties (= be able to speak, hear, see, understand, etc.)
intellectual/critical/artistic faculties

senses.definition: a particular ability for doing something

examples.en: the faculty of understanding complex issues
He had a faculty for seeing his own mistakes.
our faculty for picking up speech even in noisy environments

senses.definition: to become or to make something become paler or less bright

examples.en: The curtains had faded in the sun.
All colour had faded from the sky.
The sun had faded the curtains.
He was wearing faded blue jeans.

senses.definition: to disappear gradually

examples.en: Her smile faded.
Hopes of reaching an agreement seem to be fading away.
The laughter faded away.
The smile faded from his face.
His voice faded to a whisper (= gradually became quieter).
All other issues fade into insignificance compared with the struggle for survival.
Summer was fading into autumn.

senses.definition: if a sports player, team, actor, etc. fades, they stop playing or performing as well as they did before

examples.en: Black faded on the final bend.

senses.definition: to be disappearing quickly

examples.en: Hopes of a peace settlement were fading fast.

senses.definition: to behave in a way that does not attract any attention; to disappear or hide
to not be successful in achieving something

examples.en: Many diets fail because they are boring.
Ultimately all their efforts failed.
a policy/plan fails
I failed in my attempt to persuade her.
He failed in his bid for the presidency.
The department failed to meet its sales targets.
They promised a lot, but utterly failed to deliver.
The song can't fail to be a hit (= definitely will be a hit).

senses.definition: to not pass a test or an exam; to decide that somebody/something has not passed a test or an exam

examples.en: What will you do if you fail?
He failed his driving test.
Students who fail the exam can retake it.
She was disqualified after failing a drugs test.
The restaurant failed a hygiene inspection.
The examiners failed over half the candidates.

senses.definition: to not do something

examples.en: People failed to recognize her talent.
His article fails to mention that he actually supported this change.
If you fail to comply, you can be fined.
The government has failed to provide the needed resources.
Such comments never failed to annoy him.
I fail to see (= I don't understand) why you won't even give it a try.
She cannot fail to (= must) be aware of the situation.
They failed in their duty to protect the public.

senses.definition: to stop working

examples.en: The brakes on my bike failed half way down the hill.
The air-conditioning system failed on the hottest day of the year.
Sadly, his kidneys had failed.

senses.definition: to become weak

examples.en: Her eyesight is failing.
The light began to fail.

senses.definition: to disappoint somebody; to be unable to help when needed

examples.en: When he lost his job, he felt he had failed his family.
She tried to be brave, but her courage failed her.
Words fail me (= I cannot express how I feel).

senses.definition: to not be enough when needed or expected

examples.en: The crops failed again last summer.
The rains had failed and the rivers were dry.

senses.definition: to be unable to continue

examples.en: Several banks failed during the recession.

senses.definition: used to suggest something that somebody can do if nothing else they have tried is successful

examples.en: If all else fails, you can always sell your motorbike.

senses.definition: so important to the economy of a country that when it finds itself in financial trouble, the government or central bank must act to save it

examples.en: Shouldering the huge costs of rescuing banks that are too big to fail has been left to taxpayers.

senses.definition: the result of an exam in which a person is not successful

examples.en: I got three passes and one fail.

senses.definition: a mistake or lack of success in doing something

examples.en: The show was an epic fail.
For the sake of that potential, I'm willing to put up with some fail.

senses.definition: when you tell somebody to do something without fail, you are telling them that they must do it

examples.en: I want you here by two o'clock without fail.

senses.definition: always

examples.en: He hands in his assignment every week without fail.

senses.definition: not successful

examples.en: a failed writer
a failed coup

senses.definition: lack of success in doing or achieving something

examples.en: The success or failure of the plan depends on you.
She is still coming to terms with the failure of her marriage.
The attempt was doomed to failure.
All my efforts ended in failure.
the problems of economic failure and increasing unemployment
Their bid to win the contract resulted in abject failure.
The decision to withdraw funding represents a failure of imagination.
the intelligence failures that preceded the terrorist attacks

senses.definition: a person or thing that is not successful

examples.en: The whole thing was a complete failure.
A team learns from experience, both successes and failures.
He was a failure as a teacher.

senses.definition: an act of not doing something, especially something that you are expected to do

examples.en: Failure to comply with the regulations will result in prosecution.
the city's failure to provide an efficient public transport system
the government's failure to carry out reforms in the energy sector
His confession followed repeated failures to appear in court.

examples.cf: failure of somebody/something to do something
examples.en: the failure of the United Nations to maintain food supplies

examples.cf: failure by somebody/something to do something
examples.en: a report on the failure by the police to protect her

senses.definition: the state of not working correctly or as expected; an occasion when this happens

examples.en: patients suffering from heart/kidney/liver failure
renal/respiratory failure
Production has been hampered by mechanical failure.
A power failure plunged everything into darkness.
The cause of the crash was given as engine failure.
Poor maintenance caused the failure of two electricity generators.

senses.definition: a situation in which a business has to close because it is not successful

examples.en: There has been an alarming increase in business failures.
Are we going to see more closures or failures in the ISP business?
Business failures rose by 30% in 2023.

senses.definition: a situation in which crops do not grow correctly and do not produce food

examples.en: Bad weather has resulted in crop failure.

senses.definition: acceptable and appropriate in a particular situation

examples.en: a fair deal/wage/price
The punishment was very fair.
In the end, a draw was a fair result.
I give you fair warning, I’m not always this generous.
We wanted to resolve this matter in a way that would be fair to her.

examples.cf: fair to somebody to do something
examples.en: Was it really fair to him to ask him to do all the work?
Moving to a new city wouldn't have been fair on the kids.

examples.cf: fair on somebody to do something
examples.en: It's not fair on the students to keep changing the timetable.

examples.cf: it is fair to do something
examples.en: It's only fair to add that they were not told about the problem until the last minute.
I think it is fair to say that they are pleased with this latest offer.
It's fair that they should give us something in return.
To be fair, she behaved better than we expected.
‘You should really have asked me first.’ ‘Right, okay, fair comment.’

senses.definition: treating everyone equally and according to the rules or law

examples.en: She has always been scrupulously fair.
They are fair and decent employers.
demands for a fairer distribution of wealth
his vision of a fairer, kinder society
The new tax is fairer than the old system.
We have to be fair to both players.
to receive a fair trial
For the first time, free and fair elections will be held.
It's not fair! He always gets more than me.

senses.definition: pale in colour

examples.en: a fair complexion
Kate had dark hair and fair skin.
She has long fair hair.
All her children are fair (= they all have fair hair).

senses.definition: quite large in number, size or amount

examples.en: A fair number of people came along.
There's been a fair amount of research on this topic.
a fair-sized town
We've still got a fair bit (= quite a lot) to do.
My birthday’s still a fair way off (= it’s still a long time until my birthday).

senses.definition: quite good

examples.en: There's a fair chance that we might win this time.
It's a fair bet that they won't turn up.
I have a fair idea of what happened.
His knowledge of French is only fair.
Scoring twenty points was a fair achievement.

senses.definition: bright and not raining

examples.en: It was a fair and breezy day.
The day was set fair with the spring sun shining down.

senses.definition: not too strong and blowing in the right direction

examples.en: They set sail with the first fair wind.

senses.definition: beautiful

examples.en: a fair maiden

idioms.word: all’s fair in love and war

senses.definition: in some situations any type of behaviour is acceptable to get what you want
used to tell somebody to be reasonable in their judgement of somebody/something

examples.en: Be fair! She didn't know you were coming.

senses.definition: using dishonest methods if honest ones do not work

examples.en: She’s determined to win, by fair means or foul.

idioms.word: a fair crack of the whip

senses.definition: a reasonable opportunity to show that you can do something

examples.en: I felt we weren't given a fair crack of the whip.

senses.definition: used to say that an idea or suggestion seems reasonable

examples.en: ‘We'll meet at 8.’ ‘Fair enough.’
If you don't want to come, fair enough, but let Bill know.

variants.html: (British English also a good few)

senses.definition: a fairly large number

examples.en: I've been there a fair few times.

senses.definition: used to ask somebody to be reasonable

examples.en: I just wanted to say, ‘Hey mate, fair go!’

senses.definition: (to allow somebody) the opportunity to give their opinion of something before deciding if they have done something wrong, often in court

examples.en: I'll see that you get a fair hearing.

variants.html: (British English also fair dos/do’s)

senses.definition: used to ask for fair treatment or to claim that a situation is fair

examples.en: Fair's fair—we were here first.
Fair's fair—you can't expect them to cancel everything just because you can't make it.
Come on, fair's fair—you’ve had your chance, now let me try.

variants.text: (Australian English, New Zealand English (give somebody/get) a fair go)
variants.html: (Australian English, New Zealand English (give somebody/get) a fair go)

senses.definition: (to give somebody/get) fair treatment that gives you the same chance as somebody else

examples.en: Are minority students getting a fair shake at college?
We need a government that cares about equity and a fair go for all.

idioms.word: (more than) your fair share of something

senses.definition: (more than) an amount of something that is considered to be reasonable or acceptable

examples.en: He has more than his fair share of problems.
I've had my fair share of success in the past.

senses.definition: not particularly good or bad

examples.en: ‘How are you feeling today?’ ‘Oh, fair to middling.’

senses.definition: used by somebody who is caught doing something wrong, to say that they admit that they are wrong
according to the rules; in a way that is considered to be acceptable and appropriate

examples.en: Come on, you two, fight fair!
They'll respect you as long as you play fair (= behave honestly).

idioms.word: fair and square | fairly and squarely

senses.definition: honestly and according to the rules

examples.en: We won the election fair and square.

senses.definition: in a direct way that is easy to understand

examples.en: I told him fair and square to pack his bags.

senses.definition: exactly in the place you were aiming for

examples.en: I hit the target fair and square.

senses.definition: having the necessary qualities or conditions to succeed

examples.en: She seems set fair to win the championship.
Conditions were set fair for stable economic development.

senses.definition: used to say that you think the offer you are making is reasonable or generous

examples.en: Look, I'll give you £100 for it. You can't say fairer than that.

variants.html: (British English also funfair)

senses.definition: a type of entertainment in a field or park at which people can ride on large machines and play games to win prizes

examples.en: Let's take the kids to the fair.
all the fun of the fair

senses.definition: a type of entertainment in a field or park at which farm animals and products are shown and take part in competitions

examples.en: the county/state fair
We all went south for the state fair.

variants.html: (also fete, fête (all British English))

senses.definition: an outdoor entertainment at which people can play games to win prizes, buy food and drink, etc., usually arranged to make money for a special purpose
an event at which people, businesses, etc. show and sell their goods

examples.en: a world trade fair
a craft/a book/an antique fair

senses.definition: (in the past) a market at which animals were sold

examples.en: a horse fair

senses.definition: an event at which people who are looking for jobs can get information about companies who might employ them
to some extent but not very

examples.en: fairly simple/easy/straightforward
This is a fairly common problem.
It's fairly obvious what's going on here.
It's fairly clear that there is still room for improvement.
That's a fairly typical reaction.
I know him fairly well, but I wouldn't say we were really close friends.
We'll have to leave fairly soon (= before very long).
I'm fairly certain I can do the job.
He was fairly sure he was right.
I think you'll find it fairly difficult (= you do not want to say that it is very difficult).

senses.definition: in a fair and reasonable way; honestly

examples.en: He has always treated me very fairly.
Her attitude could fairly be described as hostile.

senses.definition: used to emphasize something that you are saying

examples.en: The time fairly raced by.

variants.html: (also fair and square)

senses.definition: honestly and according to the rules
in a direct way that is easy to understand
exactly in the place you were aiming for
the quality of treating people equally or in a way that is reasonable

examples.en: The fairness of the judicial system is being questioned.
She has a strong sense of justice and fairness.

senses.definition: a pale colour of skin or hair

examples.en: A tan emphasized the fairness of her hair.

senses.definition: used to introduce a statement that defends somebody who has just been criticized, or that explains another statement that may seem unreasonable

examples.en: In all fairness to him, he did try to stop her leaving.
I have in fairness to say that, as yet, there is no hard evidence to support these charges.
In all fairness to him, I should say that most of his story is true.

senses.definition: trust in somebody’s ability or knowledge; trust that somebody/something will do what has been promised

examples.en: If the company can retain its customers' faith, it could become the market leader.
I have faith in you—I know you'll do well.
We've lost faith in the government's promises.
Her friend's kindness has restored her faith in human nature.
I wouldn't put too much faith in what she says.
He has blind faith (= unreasonable trust) in doctors' ability to find a cure.

senses.definition: strong religious belief

examples.en: to have faith
to lose your faith
Faith is stronger than reason.
a woman of strong religious faith
He started questioning his faith in God.

senses.definition: a particular religion

examples.en: the Christian/Catholic/Islamic/Muslim/Jewish faith
The children are learning to understand people of different faiths.
people of all faiths and none

senses.definition: the intention to do something right/wrong

examples.en: They handed over the weapons as a gesture of good faith.
The judge did not find any bad faith on the part of the defendants.

senses.definition: to break/keep a promise that you have made to somebody; to stop/continue supporting somebody

examples.en: As club manager he was not prepared to keep faith with the players who had failed him.

senses.definition: knowing that what you are doing is wrong

examples.en: They had entered into the contract in bad faith.

senses.definition: believing that what you are doing is right; believing that something is correct

examples.en: We printed the report in good faith but have now learnt that it was incorrect.
He bought the painting in good faith (= he did not know that it had been stolen).

senses.definition: a belief in something that is not known or has not been done before

examples.en: These reforms are totally untested and will require a leap of faith on the part of teachers.

variants.html: (also pin (all) your hopes on somebody/something )

senses.definition: to rely on somebody/something completely for success or help

examples.en: She did not pin much faith on their chances of success.

senses.definition: a first name for girls
not what somebody claims it is; appearing to be something it is not

examples.en: There were a few stalls selling fake designer clothing.
The caller appeared to have a fake American accent.

senses.definition: made to look like something else

examples.en: a fake fur jacket
Don't go out in the sun—get a fake tan from a bottle.
We sprayed fake snow over the trees to make it look like winter.

senses.definition: an object such as a work of art, a coin or a piece of jewellery that is not what somebody claims it is but has been made to look as if it is

examples.en: All the paintings proved to be fakes.
She had long ago sold the diamonds and replaced them with fakes.

senses.definition: a person who pretends to be what they are not in order to cheat people
to make something false appear to be real, especially in order to cheat somebody

examples.en: She faked her mother's signature on the document.
He arranged the accident in order to fake his own death.

senses.definition: to pretend to have a particular feeling, illness, etc.

examples.en: She's not really sick—she's just faking it.
He faked a yawn.

senses.definition: to drop down from a higher level to a lower level

examples.en: The rain was falling steadily.
They were injured by falling rocks.
Several of the books had fallen onto the floor.
The label must have fallen off.
The leaves were falling from the trees.
The seeds fall to the ground and germinate.
One of the kids fell into the river.
He fell 20 metres onto the rocks below.

senses.definition: to suddenly stop standing

examples.en: She slipped on the ice and fell.
A tree fell, just missing his car.
I fell over and cut my knee.
The house looked as if it was about to fall down.

senses.definition: to decrease in amount, number or strength

examples.en: Prices continued to fall on the stock market today.
The temperature fell sharply in the night.
Falling birth rates could have an impact on future economic growth.
Reputations rise and fall for a variety of reasons.
Their profits have fallen by 30 per cent.
Share prices fell 30p.
Petroleum sales fell almost 11 per cent.
The dollar fell slightly against the yen.
Her voice fell to a whisper.
Unemployment fell to its lowest level in 25 years.

senses.definition: to pass into a particular state; to begin to be something

examples.en: He had fallen asleep on the sofa.
She fell ill soon after and did not recover.
The room had fallen silent.
When the rent fell due, she couldn't pay.
The book fell open at a page of illustrations.
I had fallen into conversation with a man on the train.
The house had fallen into disrepair.

senses.definition: to hang down

examples.en: Her hair fell over her shoulders in a mass of curls.

senses.definition: to slope downwards

examples.en: The land falls away sharply towards the river.

senses.definition: to be defeated or captured

examples.en: The coup failed but the government fell shortly afterwards.
Troy finally fell to the Greeks.

senses.definition: to die in battle; to be shot

examples.en: a memorial to those who fell in the two world wars

senses.definition: to come quickly and suddenly

examples.en: A sudden silence fell.
Darkness falls quickly in the tropics.
An expectant hush fell on the guests.

senses.definition: to happen or take place

examples.en: My birthday falls on a Monday this year.

senses.definition: to move in a particular direction or come in a particular position

examples.en: My eye fell on (= I suddenly saw) a curious object.
Which syllable does the stress fall on?
A shadow fell across her face.

senses.definition: to belong to a particular class, group or area of responsibility

examples.en: Out of over 400 staff there are just seven that fall into this category.
This case falls outside my jurisdiction.
This falls under the heading of scientific research.

senses.definition: an act of falling

examples.en: I had a bad fall and broke my arm.
She was killed in a fall from a horse.

senses.definition: an amount of snow, rain, rocks, etc. that falls or has fallen

examples.en: a heavy fall of snow
a rock fall

variants.html: (also especially British English autumn)

senses.definition: the season of the year between summer and winter, when leaves change colour and the weather becomes colder

examples.en: in the fall of 2023
last fall
Cool, damp fall weather brings out snails.
He returned to school a month into the fall semester.

senses.definition: a decrease in size, number, rate or level

examples.en: Share prices suffered a slight fall yesterday.
a sharp fall in prices
a steep/dramatic fall in profits
a 3 per cent fall in unemployment

senses.definition: a loss of political, economic, etc. power or success; the loss or defeat of a city, country, etc. in war

examples.en: the fall of the Roman Empire
the rise and fall of British industry
the fall of Berlin

senses.definition: a situation in which a person, an organization, etc. loses the respect of other people because they have done something wrong

examples.en: the TV preacher’s spectacular fall from grace
His diary charts his dramatic fall from grace.

senses.definition: a large amount of water falling down from a height

examples.en: The falls upstream are full of salmon.
Niagara Falls

senses.definition: the way in which something falls or happens

examples.en: the fall of the dice
the dark fall of her hair (= the way her hair hangs down)

senses.definition: the occasion when Adam and Eve did not obey God and had to leave the Garden of Eden
to be doing something that involves risks and that may end in disaster
to stop somebody from falling onto something hard

examples.en: Luckily, a bush broke his fall.

senses.definition: if you have too high an opinion of yourself or your abilities, something will happen to make you look stupid
to accept responsibility or punishment for something that you did not do, or did not do alone

examples.en: He took the fall for his boss and resigned.
Who will take the fall for the scandal?
Someone has to take the fall.

senses.definition: wrong; not correct or true

examples.en: A whale is a fish. True or false?
Predictions of an early improvement in the housing market proved false.
She gave false information to the insurance company.
He used a false name to get the job.
His career was ruined by false accusations.
The allegations are completely false.
This claim is simply false.
The law can punish knowingly false statements.

senses.definition: not natural

examples.en: false teeth/eyelashes
a false beard

senses.definition: not real or what somebody claims it is, but made to look real to cheat people

examples.en: He had been travelling with a false passport.
The case had a false bottom where documents or even a small radio could be hidden.

senses.definition: wrong or not accurate, because it is based on something that is not true or correct

examples.en: a false argument/assumption/belief
to give a false impression of wealth
to lull somebody into a false sense of security (= make somebody feel safe when they are really in danger)
They didn't want to raise any false hopes, but they believed her husband had escaped capture.
Buying a cheap computer is a false economy (= will not actually save you money).
If you don't do the test right, it can lead to false positives.

senses.definition: not real or sincere

examples.en: false modesty
She flashed him a false smile of congratulation.

senses.definition: not faithful

examples.en: a false lover

senses.definition: by pretending to be something that you are not, in order to gain some advantage for yourself

examples.en: She was accused of obtaining money under false pretences.

senses.definition: to give the impression of being sincere/true or not sincere/true

examples.en: It may seem a strange story but it rings true to me.
His expressions of support rang rather hollow.
His promise rang hollow.

senses.definition: the state of being known and talked about by many people

examples.en: to achieve/win instant fame
Daisy Ridley of ‘Star Wars’ fame (= famous for ‘Star Wars’)
The town's only claim to fame is that there was once a riot there.
She went to Hollywood in search of fame and fortune.

senses.definition: a short period of being famous

examples.en: Everybody wants their fifteen minutes of fame.

senses.definition: to suddenly become famous, especially as a singer or actor

examples.en: He shot to fame almost overnight.
She shot to stardom in a Broadway musical.

senses.definition: well known to you; often seen or heard and therefore easy to recognize

examples.en: to look/sound/seem familiar
I couldn’t see any familiar faces in the room.
He's a familiar figure in the neighbourhood.
Then she heard a familiar voice.
The cast contains a number of familiar names.
The song was vaguely familiar.
The smell is very familiar to everyone who lives near a bakery.
Violent attacks are becoming all too familiar (= sadly familiar).

senses.definition: knowing something very well

examples.en: an area with which I had been familiar since childhood
You will soon become familiar with the different activities.
Are you familiar with the computer software they use?
She would have been familiar with the work of this 18th-century German philosopher.
Ishii is clearly intimately familiar with his script and characters.

senses.definition: very informal, sometimes in a way that is unpleasant

examples.en: You seem to be on very familiar terms with your tutor.
After a few drinks her boss started getting too familiar for her liking.
He was being overly familiar with Gloria.

senses.definition: a group consisting of one or two parents and their children

examples.en: I introduced Neil to the other members of my family.
The event promises games and fun for the entire family.
This is a summer movie for the whole family.
Every family has its own story to tell.
All my family enjoy skiing.
one-parent/single-parent families
Taking a family of four to the cinema is expensive.
families with young children
He's a friend of the family (= he is known and liked by the parents and the children).
From early childhood he was a mystery to the rest of his family.
I barely earn enough money to pay my rent and feed my family.
She works tirelessly to provide for her family.
Her family has/have always supported her.

senses.definition: a group consisting of one or two parents, their children and close relations

examples.en: All our family came to Grandad's eightieth birthday party.
The support of family and friends is vital.
We've only told the immediate family (= the closest relations).
the royal family (= the children and close relations of the king or queen)
I always think of you as one of the family.
There are a lot of girls in our family.
Nobody outside his family knew that he had a daughter.
We all knew her so well that we felt she was almost part of the family.
She's family (= she is a relation).
We have family in France.
My family always tells/tell me what they think.

senses.definition: all the people who are related to each other, including those who are now dead

examples.en: Some families have farmed in this area for hundreds of years.
This painting has been in our family for generations.
He belonged to an aristocratic family.
She is of Muslim heritage on her father's side of the family.
My family has/have always lived here.

senses.definition: a couple’s or a person’s children, especially young children

examples.en: They have a large family.
I addressed it to Mr and Mrs Jones and family.
Do they plan to start a family (= have children)?
This is a wonderful place to raise a family.
She brought up a family of six children on her own.
She chose to stop work to have a family.
My family is/are a lively bunch.

senses.definition: a group into which animals, plants, etc. that have similar characteristics are divided, smaller than an order and larger than a genus

examples.en: Lions belong to the cat family.
This bird is a member of the crow family.
Orchids are the largest family of flowering plants.

senses.definition: a group of related languages

examples.en: the Germanic family of languages

senses.definition: (to be/become) pregnant
to be a common feature in a particular family

examples.en: Heart disease runs in the family.
a medical condition which runs in the family

senses.definition: connected with the family or a particular family

examples.en: family life
The job was starting to affect his family life.
your family background
Only close family members called her ‘Sally’.
a family friend (= a friend of the whole family)
family ties/connections
It's a family tradition.
She has become interested in her family history.
He has a family history of heart disease.

senses.definition: owned by a family

examples.en: They had to sell the family home.
a family business
the family car
She had to sell the family jewels in order to pay off her gambling debts.

senses.definition: suitable for all members of a family, both adults and children

examples.en: a family show
family entertainment

senses.definition: known about by many people

examples.en: a famous artist/actor
The actor was one of many famous faces at the party.
Loch Ness is probably the most famous lake in Scotland.
Tiger Woods is one of the most famous names in golf.
Many rich and famous people have stayed at the hotel.
So this is the famous dress! (= the one we have heard a lot about but have not seen).
The song was made famous by Frank Sinatra.
This was the book that made her famous.
He became internationally famous for his novels.
She was more famous as a writer than as a singer.

senses.definition: people who are known about by many people

examples.en: the lifestyles of the rich and famous

senses.definition: people sometimes say Famous last words! when they think somebody is being too confident about something that is going to happen

examples.en: ‘Everything's under control.’ ‘Famous last words!’

senses.definition: a person who admires somebody/something or enjoys watching or listening to somebody/something very much

examples.en: sports/music fans
Movie fans will be familiar with his work already.
Crowds of football fans filled the streets.
I like his films, but I wouldn't say I'm a diehard fan (= one who strongly admires somebody/something in all circumstances).
I'm a big fan of her books.
I'm a huge fan of Rihanna.
I'm not a great fan of bushy beards (= I don't like them).

senses.definition: a machine that creates a current of air

examples.en: to switch on the electric fan
a fan heater
a fan blowing cold air

senses.definition: a thing that you hold in your hand and wave to create a current of cool air

idioms.word: when the shit hits the fan

senses.definition: when somebody in authority finds out about something bad or wrong that somebody has done

examples.en: When the shit hits the fan, I don't want to be here.

senses.definition: to make air blow onto somebody/something by waving a fan, your hand, etc.

examples.en: He fanned himself with a newspaper to cool down.
A warm breeze fanned her cheeks.

senses.definition: to make a fire burn more strongly by blowing on it

examples.en: Fanned by a westerly wind, the fire spread rapidly through the city.

senses.definition: to make a feeling, an attitude, etc. stronger

examples.en: His reluctance to answer her questions simply fanned her curiosity.

senses.definition: to make a feeling such as anger, hate, etc. worse

examples.en: His writings fanned the flames of racism.

senses.definition: to want something or want to do something

examples.en: Fancy a drink?
I fancied a change of scene.
She didn't fancy (= did not like) the idea of going home in the dark.
Do you fancy going out this evening?

senses.definition: to be sexually attracted to somebody

examples.en: I think she fancies me.

senses.definition: to think that you are very popular, attractive or intelligent

examples.en: He started to chat to me and I could tell that he really fancied himself.

senses.definition: to like the idea of being something or to believe, often wrongly, that you are something

examples.en: She fancies herself (as) a serious actress.
He fancied himself in love with me, the silly boy.

senses.definition: used to show that you are surprised or shocked by something

examples.en: Fancy! She's never been in a plane before.
Fancy meeting you here!
‘She remembered my name after all those years.’ ‘Fancy that!’

senses.definition: to think that somebody/something will win or be successful at something, especially in a race

examples.en: Which horse do you fancy in the next race?
He's hoping to get the job but I don't fancy his chances.

senses.definition: to believe or imagine something

examples.en: She fancied (that) she could hear footsteps.

senses.definition: unusually complicated, often in an unnecessary way; intended to impress other people

examples.en: a kitchen full of fancy gadgets
They added a lot of fancy footwork to the dance.
He's always using fancy legal words.

senses.definition: with a lot of decorations or bright colours

examples.en: fancy goods (= things sold as gifts or for decoration)
He was the fanciest dresser in the room.

senses.definition: expensive or connected with an expensive way of life

examples.en: fancy restaurants with fancy prices
Don't come back with any fancy ideas.

senses.definition: of high quality
something that you imagine; your imagination

examples.en: night-time fancies that disappear in the morning
a child’s wild flights of fancy

senses.definition: a feeling that you would like to have or to do something

examples.en: She said she wanted a dog but it was only a passing fancy.

senses.definition: a small decorated cake

idioms.word: as/whenever, etc. the fancy takes you

senses.definition: as/whenever, etc. you feel like doing something

examples.en: We bought a camper van so we could go away whenever the fancy took us.

senses.definition: to attract or please somebody

examples.en: She looked through the hotel advertisements until one of them caught her fancy.

senses.definition: to start liking somebody/something, often without an obvious reason

examples.en: He’s taken quite a fancy to his next-door neighbour.

senses.definition: to please somebody

examples.en: See if any of these tickle your fancy.
If you see something that tickles your fancy, I’ll buy it for you.

senses.definition: extremely good; excellent

examples.en: He's done a fantastic job.
This was a fantastic opportunity for students.
You look fantastic!
It was a fantastic achievement.
The weather was absolutely fantastic.
You've got the job? Fantastic!

examples.cf: it is fantastic to do something
examples.en: It was fantastic to see so many families enjoying themselves.

senses.definition: very large; larger than you expected

examples.en: The response to our appeal was fantastic.
The car costs a fantastic amount of money.

variants.html: (also less frequent fantastical)

senses.definition: strange and showing a lot of imagination

examples.en: fantastic dreams of forests and jungles

senses.definition: impossible to put into practice; impossible to believe

examples.en: a fantastic scheme/project
It may sound rather fantastic, but it's the truth.
The plot gets increasingly fantastic as the film goes on.

senses.definition: a pleasant situation that you imagine but that is unlikely to happen

examples.en: He spoke of his childhood fantasies about becoming a famous football player.

senses.definition: a product of your imagination

examples.en: Her books are usually escapist fantasies.

senses.definition: the act of imagining things; a person’s imagination

examples.en: This is a work of fantasy.
Stop living in a fantasy world.
I live in the real world, not fantasy land.

senses.definition: a type of story that is set in a world, or a version of our world, that does not really exist and involves magic, monsters, etc.

examples.en: She wrote a series of fantasy novels filled with wizards, witches and dragons.

senses.definition: a competition in which you choose players to make your own imaginary team, and score points according to the performance of the real players

examples.en: In his personal time, Stephen blogs for several fantasy hockey leagues.

senses.definition: a long distance away

examples.en: We didn't go far.
Have you come far?
It's not far to the beach.
There's not far to go now.
It's too far to walk.
The restaurant is not far from here.
countries as far apart as Japan and Brazil
He looked down at the traffic far below.
Far away in the distance, a train whistled.
The farther north they went, the colder it became.
a concert of music from near and far
Legends are usually far removed from the reality.

senses.definition: used when you are asking or talking about the distance between two places or the distance that has been travelled or is to be travelled

examples.en: How far is it to your house from here?
How far is Boston from New York?
How much further is it?
I'm not sure I can walk so far.
We'll go by train as far as London, and then take a bus.
We didn't go as far as the others.

senses.definition: a long time from the present; for a large part of a particular period of time

examples.en: The band had their first hit as far back as 2012.
To answer that question we need to go further back in time.
Let's try to plan further ahead.
We worked far into the night.
The film takes place in a future not too far distant.

senses.definition: very much; to a great degree

examples.en: That's a far better idea.
The damage was far worse than I'd expected.
a drug that gives heart attack victims a far greater chance of survival
There are far more opportunities for young people than there used to be.
She always gives us far too much homework.
The results far exceeded my expectations.
The benefits far outweigh the cost.
The recent heat and continued drought further reduced yields.
It had been a success far beyond their expectations.
He's fallen far behind in his work.

senses.definition: used when you are asking or talking about the degree to which something is true or possible

examples.en: How far can we trust him?
His parents supported him as far as they could.
Plan your route in advance, using main roads as far as possible.

senses.definition: used to talk about how much progress has been made in doing or achieving something

examples.en: How far have you got with that report?
Half an hour later Duncan was no farther in his quest.
I read as far as the third chapter.
We’ve got as far as collecting our data but we haven’t analysed it yet.

idioms.word: as far as the eye can/could see

senses.definition: to the horizon (= where the sky meets the land or sea)

examples.en: The bleak moorland stretched on all sides as far as the eye could see.

idioms.word: as/so far as I am concerned

senses.definition: used to give your personal opinion on something

examples.en: As far as I am concerned, you can do what you like.

idioms.word: as far as I know | as far as I can remember, see, tell, etc.

senses.definition: used to say that you think you know, remember, understand, etc. something but you cannot be completely sure, especially because you do not know all the facts

examples.en: As far as we knew, there was no cause for concern.
As far as I can see, you've done nothing wrong.
She lived in Chicago, as far as I can remember.

idioms.word: as/so far as somebody/something is concerned

variants.html: (also as/so far as somebody/something goes)

senses.definition: used to give facts or an opinion about a particular aspect of something

examples.en: She's doing fine as far as French is concerned, it's her German I'm worried about.

senses.definition: to a limited degree, usually less than is enough

examples.en: It's a good plan as far as it goes, but there are a lot of things they haven't thought of.

senses.definition: by a great amount

examples.en: The last of these reasons is by far the most important.
Amy is the smartest by far.

senses.definition: to continue doing something beyond reasonable limits
far away from home; to or in places that are not near

examples.en: You can hire a car if you want to explore further afield.
People commute to London from as far afield as France.

senses.definition: by a very great amount

examples.en: She's far and away the best player.

senses.definition: over a large area

examples.en: They searched far and wide for the missing child.
People came from far and wide for the show.

idioms.word: far be it from me to do something (but…)

senses.definition: used when you are just about to disagree with somebody or to criticize them and you would like them to think that you do not really want to do this

examples.en: Far be it from me to interfere in your affairs but I would like to give you just one piece of advice.

senses.definition: almost the opposite of something or of what is expected

examples.en: It is far from clear (= it is not clear) what he intends to do.
New technology, far from destroying jobs, can create employment.

fashionable and attractive
able to fly

senses.definition: moving rapidly through the air

examples.en: flying lessons
a flying instructor

senses.definition: a point or distance at which the outline of an object is clearly seen by the eye or through a lens

senses.definition: a point at which waves of light, sound, etc. meet after reflection or refraction; the point from which waves of light, sound, etc. seem to come

senses.definition: to put your arms around somebody and hold them against your body

examples.en: to increase tenfold

senses.definition: people in general

senses.definition: considering what can be expected from somebody/something

senses.definition: being used

examples.en: I know what he did was wrong but don’t you think it’s time to forgive and forget?

senses.definition: a tool with a handle and three or four sharp points (called prongs), used for picking up and eating food

senses.definition: of any type

examples.en: The ground was frozen solid.
They adapted to the harsh conditions of the frozen north.

senses.definition: unable to move because of a strong emotion such as fear or horror

examples.en: She stared at him, frozen with shock.
His white face was frozen in fear.
I stood frozen to the spot, unable to speak.

senses.definition: the part of a plant that consists of one or more seeds and a soft inner part, can be eaten as food and usually tastes sweet

examples.en: tropical fruits, such as bananas and pineapples
citrus fruits, such as oranges and lemons
Eat plenty of fresh fruit and vegetables.
Eat five daily portions of fruit and vegetables.
a piece of fruit (= an apple, an orange, etc.)
The colour indicates when the fruit is ripe.
Whole fruits contain more fibre than fruit juice.
The orchard has over 300 fruit trees.

senses.definition: a part of a plant or tree that is formed after the flowers have died and in which seeds develop

examples.en: The crab apple bears a small, bitter fruit.

senses.definition: all the natural things that the earth produces
an offensive word for a gay man
to have a successful result
a thing that is not allowed and that therefore seems very attractive

examples.en: Well, you know what they say— forbidden fruit tastes sweetest.

senses.definition: the good results of an activity or a situation

examples.en: to enjoy the fruits of your labours (= the rewards for your hard work)
The book is the fruit of years of research.

senses.definition: to produce fruit
feeling annoyed and impatient because you cannot do or achieve what you want

examples.en: It's very easy to get frustrated in this job.
His apathy just made her even more frustrated.
They felt frustrated at the lack of progress.

senses.definition: having no effect; not being satisfied

examples.en: He stamped his foot in frustrated rage.
frustrated desires

senses.definition: unable to be successful in a particular career

examples.en: a frustrated artist

senses.definition: not satisfied sexually
causing you to feel annoyed and impatient because you cannot do or achieve what you want

examples.en: It's frustrating to have to wait so long.
The frustrating thing is, they probably won’t even be in when we get there.

senses.definition: the feeling of being frustrated

examples.en: Dave thumped the table in frustration.
She couldn't stand the frustration of not being able to help.
sexual frustration

senses.definition: something that causes you to feel frustrated

examples.en: Every job has its difficulties and frustrations.
She took out her frustrations on the children.
My biggest frustration was not having enough time.

senses.definition: the fact that something is preventing something/somebody from succeeding

examples.en: the frustration of all his ambitions

senses.definition: to cook something in hot fat or oil; to be cooked in hot fat or oil

examples.en: fried fish
We had fried chicken for dinner.
the smell of bacon frying
Fry the onions gently in oil.

senses.definition: to be burnt by the sun

examples.en: You'll fry on the beach if you're not careful.

senses.definition: to have more important or more interesting things to do
very small young fish

variants.html: (usually fries [plural])

senses.definition: a long thin piece of potato fried in oil or fat

examples.en: Would you like ketchup with your fries?

senses.definition: any material that produces heat or power, usually when it is burnt

examples.en: diesel/jet/rocket fuel

The plant reprocesses spent fuel from nuclear power stations.
The car has a 65-litre fuel tank.
a car with high fuel consumption
New engine designs are improving fuel efficiency.
We aim to cut emissions and boost fuel economy.
We use fuel oil to heat our house.
steadily rising fuel prices
Domestic fuel bills are set to rise again in the autumn.

senses.definition: a thing that is said or done that makes something, especially an argument, continue or get worse

examples.en: The new information adds fuel to the debate over safety procedures.
The revelations gave new fuel to angry opponents of the proposed law.
His remarks simply added fuel to the fire/flames of her rage.

senses.definition: to supply something with material that can be burnt to produce heat or power

examples.en: Uranium is used to fuel nuclear plants.
oil-fuelled power stations
Most electric plants in California are fuelled by natural gas.

senses.definition: to put petrol into a vehicle

examples.en: The helicopter was already fuelled (up) and ready to go.

senses.definition: to increase something; to make something stronger

examples.en: to fuel rumours/fears/suspicions
Yesterday's meeting is likely to fuel further speculation about a takeover.
Higher salaries helped to fuel inflation.

variants.html: (North American English fulfill)

senses.definition: to do or achieve what was hoped for or expected

examples.en: to fulfil your dream/ambition/potential

senses.definition: to do or have what is required or necessary

examples.en: to fulfil a duty/an obligation/a promise
to fulfil the terms/conditions of an agreement
No candidate fulfils all the criteria for this position.
He had fulfilled his promise to his father.
Once they had fulfilled their obligations, they were allowed to go.
Failure to fulfil the terms of the agreements may result in legal action.
Work permits are only given to people who fulfil certain criteria.

senses.definition: to have a particular role or purpose

examples.en: Nursery schools should fulfil the function of preparing children for school.

senses.definition: to make somebody feel happy and satisfied with what they are doing or have done

examples.en: I need a job that really fulfils me.

senses.definition: to pack and send something that a customer has ordered

examples.en: We aim to fulfil all orders within seven days.
Huge demand led to customers waiting weeks to see their orders finally fulfilled.

senses.definition: containing or holding as much or as many as possible; having no empty space

examples.en: a full bottle of wine
She could only nod, because her mouth was full.
The theatre was less than half full.
My suitcase was full of books.
There were cardboard boxes stuffed full of clothes.

senses.definition: having or containing a large number or amount of something/somebody

examples.en: The sky was full of brightly coloured fireworks.
The gallery was full of people.
He's always full of energy.
She was so bubbly and full of life.
Life is full of coincidences.
Our new brochure is crammed full of inspirational ideas.
She was full of admiration for the care she had received.
He smiled, his eyes full of laughter.

variants.html: (British English also full up)

senses.definition: having had enough to eat

examples.en: No more for me, thanks—I'm full up.
The kids still weren't full, so I gave them an ice cream each.
You can't run on a full stomach.

senses.definition: complete; with nothing missing

examples.en: Full details are available on request.
They sell a full range of hair and beauty products.
I still don't think we've heard the full story.
a full English breakfast
Fill in your full name and address.
It is too early to assess the full extent of the damage.
Frank is expected to make a full recovery.
A full refund will be given if the item is faulty.

senses.definition: to the highest level or greatest amount possible

examples.en: Many people don't use their computers to their full potential.

Students should take full advantage of the university's facilities.
She came round the corner at full speed.

senses.definition: busy; involving a lot of activities

examples.en: He'd had a very full life.
Her life was too full to find time for hobbies.
We went to bed exhausted after a very full day.

senses.definition: thinking or talking a lot about a particular thing

examples.en: He was full of his new job and everything he'd been doing.

senses.definition: used to emphasize an amount or a quantity

examples.en: She is a full four inches shorter than her sister.

senses.definition: appearing as a complete circle

examples.en: The moon was full, the sky clear.

senses.dis_g: (of a person or part of the body)
senses.definition: large and round. ‘Full’ is sometimes used to avoid saying ‘fat’.

examples.en: He kissed her full sensual lips.

senses.definition: made with plenty of cloth; fitting loosely

examples.en: a full skirt

senses.definition: deep, strong and rich

examples.en: He draws a unique full sound from the instrument.
the full fruity flavour of the coffee

senses.definition: not telling the truth; tending to make things seem better, worse or more important than they actually are

examples.en: ‘You are so full of it!’ she retorted furiously.

senses.definition: very proud; thinking only of yourself
including the whole of something

examples.en: The address must be printed in full.

variants.text: (North American English usually to the fullest)
variants.html: (North American English usually to the fullest)

senses.definition: to the greatest possible degree

examples.en: I've always believed in living life to the full.

senses.definition: directly

examples.en: She looked him full in the face.

senses.definition: completely

examples.en: I fully understand your motives.

She fully supports her daughter's plans.
We are fully aware of the dangers.
The classrooms are fully equipped.
Everyone cooperated fully with the investigation.

senses.definition: the whole of; as much as

senses.definition: the feeling of enjoying yourself; activities that you enjoy

examples.en: We had a lot of fun at Sarah's party.

It was great fun! You should have come too.
That was the most fun I have had in years.

The whole family can join in the fun at Water World.

senses.definition: behaviour or activities that are not serious but are meant to be enjoyed

examples.en: She's very lively and full of fun.

senses.definition: to be/become somebody that other people laugh at
activities that are not serious and that other people may think are bad

examples.en: Teaching isn't all fun and games, you know.

senses.definition: to laugh at somebody/something or make other people laugh at them, usually in an unkind way

examples.en: It's cruel to make fun of people who stammer.

senses.definition: to say unkind things about somebody/something in order to make other people laugh at them

examples.en: Her novels poke fun at the upper class.
She’s always poking fun at herself.

senses.definition: that you enjoy

examples.en: She's really fun to be with.
a film that's great fun to watch
This game looks fun!
Let's have a fun night out.
There are lots of fun things for young people to do here.

senses.definition: that provides entertainment or leisure activities

examples.en: a family fun day

senses.definition: a special activity or purpose of a person or thing

examples.en: The club serves a useful function as a meeting place.

bodily functions (= for example eating, sex, using the toilet)

senses.definition: a social event or official ceremony

senses.definition: a quantity whose value depends on the varying values of others. In the statement 2x=y, y is a function of x.

examples.en: Salary is a function of age and experience.

senses.definition: a part of a program, etc. that performs a basic operation
to work in the correct way

examples.en: We now have a functioning shower.

senses.definition: practical and useful; with little or no decoration

examples.en: Bathrooms don't have to be purely functional.

examples.en: a functional disorder (= an illness caused when an organ of the body fails to perform its function)

senses.dis_g: (especially of a machine, an organization or a system)
senses.definition: working; able to work

examples.en: The hospital will soon be fully functional.

senses.definition: an amount of money that has been saved or has been made available for a particular purpose

examples.en: a disaster relief fund
the company’s pension fund
the International Monetary Fund

senses.definition: money that is available to be spent

examples.en: government/federal funds

senses.definition: a company that manages money for people by investing it; the money managed by such a company

examples.en: Any extra money that James saves should go into a money market fund.

senses.definition: an amount or a supply of something

examples.en: a fund of knowledge

senses.definition: to provide money for something, usually something official

examples.en: Who is funding this research?
to fund a project/study/scheme

publicly funded healthcare
a federally funded housing project

senses.definition: serious and very important; affecting the most central and important parts of something

a question of fundamental importance

examples.en: Hard work is fundamental to success.

senses.definition: forming the source or base from which everything else is made; not able to be divided any further

examples.en: a fundamental particle

senses.definition: in every way that is important; completely

senses.definition: used when you are introducing a topic and stating something important about it

examples.en: Fundamentally, there are two different approaches to the problem.

senses.definition: used when you are saying what is the most important thing about somebody/something

examples.en: She is fundamentally a nice person, but she finds it difficult to communicate.

senses.definition: money for a particular purpose; the act of providing money for such a purpose

to receive/get/obtain funding for something
to provide/allocate funding for something
to withdraw/cut funding for something

senses.definition: the activity of collecting money for a charity or organization, often by organizing social events or entertainments

examples.en: The hospice is planning a major fundraising event for June.

senses.definition: a ceremony, often a religious one, for burying or cremating (= burning) a dead person

examples.en: Hundreds of people attended the funeral.
a funeral procession
a funeral march (= a sad piece of music suitable for funerals)

senses.definition: used to tell somebody that they, and nobody else, will have to deal with the unpleasant results of their own actions

senses.definition: difficult to explain or understand; strange and not as you expect

examples.en: A funny thing happened to me today.

senses.definition: seeming or likely to be wrong, illegal or dishonest

examples.en: I suspect there may be something funny going on.

examples.en: Don't you get funny with me!

senses.definition: slightly ill

examples.en: I feel a bit funny today—I don't think I'll go to work.

senses.definition: slightly crazy or strange

examples.en: That Dave's a funny chap, isn't he?

examples.en: My computer keeps going funny.

senses.definition: used to show that ‘funny’ is being used with the meaning of ‘making you laugh’
