senses.definition: used to show that ‘funny’ is being used with the meaning of ‘strange’

senses.definition: the skin of an animal with the fur still on it, used especially for making clothes

examples.en: a fur coat
the fur trade
a fur farm (= where animals are bred and killed for their fur)
fur-lined gloves
The animal is hunted for its fur.
Many models refuse to wear fur on the runway.

senses.definition: an artificial material that looks and feels like fur
a piece of clothing, especially a coat or jacket, made of real or artificial fur

examples.en: elegant ladies in furs
She was wearing her fur.

variants.text: (also scale British and North American English)
variants.html: (also scale British and North American English)

senses.definition: a hard grey-white substance that is sometimes left inside water pipes and containers for heating water
a grey-white layer that forms on a person’s tongue, especially when they are ill
very angry

examples.en: Their incompetence made me furious.
She was absolutely furious at having been deceived.
He was furious with himself for letting things get so out of control.
I'm furious that I wasn't told about it.

senses.definition: with great energy, speed or anger

examples.en: a furious debate
She drove off at a furious pace.

senses.definition: objects that can be moved, such as tables, chairs and beds, that are put into a house or an office to make it suitable for living or working in

examples.en: garden/office furniture
a dealer in antique furniture
a piece of furniture
We need to buy some new furniture.

senses.definition: a person or thing that you are so used to seeing that you no longer notice them

examples.en: I worked there so long that I became part of the furniture.

senses.definition: more; additional

examples.en: Cook for a further 2 minutes.

senses.definition: at or to a greater distance

examples.en: We had walked a bit further than I had realized.
I'm too tired to go any further.
further north/south/east/west
Two miles further on we came to a small town.
The hospital is further down the road.
Can you stand a bit further away?

senses.definition: a longer way in the past or the future

examples.en: Think further back into your childhood.

senses.definition: to a greater degree or extent

examples.en: to develop/increase/enhance/improve something further
to strengthen/support something further
Costs must be further reduced.
The police decided to investigate further.
My life is further complicated by having to work such long hours.

Nothing could be further from the truth.
Their share price fell further today.

senses.definition: in addition to what has just been said

examples.en: Further, it is important to consider the cost of repairs.

senses.definition: far away from home; to or in places that are not near

examples.en: You can hire a car if you want to explore further afield.

senses.definition: to say more about something, or make a more extreme point about it

examples.en: I would go even further and suggest that the entire government is corrupt.

senses.definition: to last longer; to serve more people

examples.en: They watered down the soup to make it go further.

idioms.word: go no further | not go any further

senses.definition: if you tell somebody that a secret will go no further, you promise not to tell it to anyone else
used to say that something is exactly what somebody needs and so they do not need to consider any other options

examples.en: Those looking for an enjoyable evening need look no further than the hotel's nightclub.

senses.definition: to take more serious action about something or speak to somebody at a higher level about it

examples.en: I am not satisfied with your explanation and intend to take the matter further.

senses.definition: to help something to develop or be successful

examples.en: They hoped the new venture would further the cause of cultural cooperation in Europe.

senses.definition: in addition to what has just been stated. Furthermore is used especially to add a point to an argument.

examples.en: He said he had not discussed the matter with her. Furthermore, he had not even contacted her.

senses.definition: the time that will come after the present or the events that will happen then

examples.en: We need to plan for the future.
The movie is set in the future.
at some point/time in the future
I don't expect any of these things to happen in the near future (= soon).

the immediate/not-too-distant/long-term/distant future

What does the future hold?
What will the cities of the future look like?
Kevin talked about his hopes for the future.

senses.definition: what will happen to somebody/something at a later time

examples.en: The company faces a very uncertain future.

senses.definition: the possibility of being successful or surviving at a later time

examples.en: They have a bright future ahead of them.

examples.en: oil futures
the futures market

senses.definition: the form of a verb that expresses what will happen after the present
for/in the period of time when you can predict what is going to happen, based on the present circumstances

examples.en: The statue will remain in the museum for the foreseeable future.

variants.html: (North American English in the future)

senses.definition: from now on

examples.en: Please be more careful in future.

idioms.word: in the not too distant future

senses.definition: not a long time in the future but fairly soon

examples.en: I hope we’ll see each other again in the not too distant future.

senses.definition: taking place or existing at a time after the present

examples.en: The land will remain untouched for future generations to enjoy.

future developments in artificial intelligence
present and future trends in industry
the ability to anticipate possible future events
She told us about her future plans.
He met his future wife at law school.
I wrote down the name of the hotel for future reference (= because it might be useful in the future).
